Comment: I said I’d vote for Rubio in the Republican primary, but not the general election. Think it through, and learn to vote tactically.  It matters tremendously who wins the Republican primary. Why? Because half the time, on average, the Republican candidate will win. Had Nikki Haley (whom I voted for in the 2024 primary), or even Ron DeSantis won the Republican primary, the world would not be nearly as fucked as it is rapidly becoming.   “Oh,” I can hear you wondering, “Why didn’t you vote in the Democratic primary, if you’re such a committed progressive?”  **Because they didn’t fucking have one.**  Look, there are many reasons why Democrats across the country register as Republicans: participate in their internal polls; let them waste money on mailings; vote for the least-bad-choice on the oppo ticket.  And if there is a chance that America will elect a Republican president in 2028 — and 2000, 2004, 2016 and 2024 suggest there’s a pretty big chance — then expressing a choice in that Republican nominee seems pretty important. Some states have “open primaries” allowing anyone to vote in any primary, but many do not.  I stand by my statement: of the many potential candidates the GOP might put forward for 2028, Rubio is far from the worst.
